Rabies infections increase in northeastern Thailand

Dr. Tawichai of the 9th Disease Prevention and Control Office announced on February 9 that there has been an increase in rabies infections in the northeastern part of Thailand over the past few months, with a total of 74 infected individuals.
A total of 74 people have been diagnosed with rabies this year (from October last year to September this year), with 67 people in Surin Province and 7 people in Buri Ram Province.
All of them have been vaccinated against rabies in the past.
The doctor is urging people to get vaccinated against rabies along with their pets, and to avoid touching the saliva of animals suspected of being infected.
Rabies can be transmitted not only by dogs but also by cats and bats.
If a person is infected and develops the disease, they will almost certainly die, but vaccination before the onset of the disease can prevent death.

FUJI Preventing accidents by developing a system for removing obstacles on the road, experimented with in-house vehicles | The Mid-Japan Economist, economic information from Aichi, Gifu, Mie and Shizuoka

FUJI (head office: Chiryu city) is a company that deals with the installation of electronic parts and the manufacture and sales of robots and machine tools. In order to prevent "forgetting" such as leaving a child in the car, it has started to develop a system.
The system is equipped with a motion sensor inside the vehicle, and when it detects human movement, it sends a notification to the phone or chat.
Currently, they are conducting a trial run of the system in their own vehicles.
In the midst of incidents caused by leaving children behind, it ensures the safety of children.
Two vehicles are being used to test the system in the after-school English conversation school for children "teracoya THANK" operated by the company in Chiryu City.
Three motion sensors, which detect human movement based on the temperature difference between the person and the surrounding environment, have been installed on the ceiling of the car.
When it detects no human presence for a given amount of time, it automatically sends a warning notification.
By linking the engine and door statuses with information, it is possible to prevent false alarms as much as possible.
The warning is sent via the cloud.
The number is registered in advance, and the call is made, or it is displayed on the chat of the PC or smartphone.
It can register multiple addresses, and is designed to prevent mistakes such as missing a call.
The demonstration experiment will continue until the end of February.
Chief Kanaya of the 2nd Division of the Innovation Promotion Department pointed out, "During the experiment, we were able to see surrounding issues that were not related to the system."
For example, it was able to identify various issues related to the school bus, such as creating an environment where the driver can concentrate on driving.
"Expand the solution," they say, putting their all into it.
The development of a system to prevent leaving people behind was triggered by a bus accident in which a bus left people behind on the side of the road in the country.
There was a proposal from employees who have young children, asking what they could do to ensure the safety of their children.

They decided to develop it by utilizing the know-how of IoT (Internet of Things) and information management using sensors, which they have cultivated through their business in FA (Factory Automation), and will start development.
FUJI's parking prevention system is selling on ease of use.
The sensors can be installed just by sticking them to the ceiling with a pin.
Since it can be easily attached to a welcome vehicle, we aim to lower the hurdle for adoption.
In the future, they will consider cooperation with daycare centers and kindergartens, and will consider productization.

The chocolate sales area for Valentine's Day, which was revived after three years, is the Seibu Fukui store in Fukui city, Fukui prefecture on February 9th.

With Valentine's Day on February 14th approaching, the price of chocolate on store shelves is rising due to the high cost of raw materials and packaging materials, but sales of high-priced chocolate for personal use and as gifts for family and friends are brisk.
In convenience stores and confectionery stores in Fukui Prefecture, products are being promoted with a focus on local color, luxury, and the use of high-quality materials to attract customers.
Seibu Fukui (Fukui) opened a special sales area on the 6th floor of the event space on January 25th.
As of the 14th, they had sold approximately 450 varieties of chocolate, including 10 confectionery stores in the prefecture.
Popular items include sandwiches made with local sake and filled with fresh chocolate, as well as cookies with the same filling.
According to the store staff, the prices of the products have risen by about 10% compared to the previous year.

This year, there are many products that stand out by focusing on the materials and packaging to give a luxury feel. Consumers seem to be buying them for themselves and their families, and for the enjoyment of eating and comparing them.
Despite the trend of rising prices, sales of high-priced items are doing well.
⇒The average price of one piece is 25 yen due to the high price of goods.

In the food and beverage industry in Fukui Prefecture, where there is a shortage of labor, the number of restaurants introducing delivery robots that bring food to the table is increasing.

A robot, which displays a cat's face on its screen while playing light music, moves smoothly around the store carrying dishes.

The "Iwasan-nuru Jingisukanbon Fukui-eki-mae-ten" restaurant in Fukui-shi, Daito-machi 2-chome, introduced a cat-shaped food delivery robot in August 2022.

The labor cost ratio to sales is usually around 30%, but it has been reduced to 21-22% by introducing the robot.

The robot also collects plates from customers after they have finished eating, which helps to improve the efficiency of cleaning up, and adds that "it is popular with families and children, and is also effective in terms of promotion."
The "Rokkan Yoshino Fukui Store" in Shinbo-cho, Araki-shinpo-machi, Fukui City, which serves grilled meat and hot pot dishes, introduced a food delivery robot in August 2022.

In Fukui store, the area where the employee serves food and the area where the robot delivers food are separated, and they are used.

In order to reduce the number of staff, the store has also introduced a tablet-based ordering system, and is considering introducing self-service.

According to the Fukui Labor Bureau, the effective recruitment ratio for the job category "customer service" in the food service industry was 6.94 times in December 2022, and it was a job category with a high shortage of labor.

A representative of the net system (Fukui-shi Takagi Chuo 2-chome) that sells delivery robots for food service said, "The labor shortage in Fukui's restaurants has become more serious due to the impact of the coronavirus, and there have been many inquiries about introducing robots."

President Hoshiyama said, "I think that it will be increasingly difficult for local suburban restaurants to secure employees in the future, and I think that delivery robots will become more widespread."
[Opinion] Echizen Town creates and distributes "Death of a Salesman" to the citizens who hope for it.

They published a "death handbook" that covers all the procedures and writing styles needed when a family member passes away, including a family tree and a list of things that need to be done, and last year, they had many people come to pick up copies for themselves.

In various parts of the prefecture, seminars on how to write an end-of-life note and how to prepare for death have been held, and it seems that "end-of-life" has become a familiar concept for citizens.
Echizen Town's Ending Note is 35 pages.

The fifth chapter starts with a summary of one's own history, and then goes on to describe one's current health and assets, as well as one's wishes for future care and end-of-life medical treatment, as well as funeral and burial arrangements.
There is also a section for things you want to do before you die and a place to leave messages for loved ones.
It seems like it would be too much to write on 35 pages, but you don't have to fill out every page.
What do you want to write down for your family and people around you the most?
The most important thing is to clarify the purpose.
There are many colourful notebooks for sale in bookstores that are suitable for the purpose, and you can start writing in them easily from the blank pages.
The term "career death" was born in 2009.
The Great East Japan Earthquake occurred in 2011, two years after the 11th year.
It is said that many people have come to realize the reality that "death comes suddenly," and that the number of people preparing for their final days and end of life has increased.
It's been about 10 years since then.
The new coronavirus that swept the world is still not under control.
The price of goods has risen due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and the electricity bill this winter has jumped to an unbelievable price.
On the other hand, wages have not kept up with the current high prices, and many people are struggling to make ends meet.
On the other hand, funeral expenses, care fees and the management of graves, which used to be shared with parents and relatives, are now the responsibility of only children.
Also, although life expectancy has increased compared to a few decades ago, the risk of dementia and care needs increases as you get older, creating a dilemma.
It is important to remember that these social anxieties are not going away, and that they are taking place against a backdrop of a transient existence.
Whatever, everyone would want to avoid putting an undue burden on their partner or children.
"Dying with dignity" is a popular phrase from the Death with Dignity movement, but it can't be taken too far.
I don't want to write a secret wish list, but rather talk to my family once about it and prepare calmly at that time.
Prime Minister Kishida Fumio (second from right) and Education Minister Nagaoka Keiko (third from right) pose with officials at a primary school they visited.
On the 10th of February, in Toda City, Saitama Prefecture, the graduation ceremony showed that wearing masks for children and teachers was not necessary as a rule.
The Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided on February 10 that students should not wear masks at graduation ceremonies, and that it is the norm not to wear them.

The principal of a large middle school said, "It is difficult to keep a wide distance between students, and I am struggling with how to respond. There are also students who feel uneasy about taking off their masks."
The issue of wearing masks at graduation ceremonies has been reported, and it is also a topic of conversation among teachers.

On the other hand, the principal of one elementary school said, "If the government says that it is necessary to wear masks, then it will be necessary to wear them. If singing is excluded, then it may be difficult to respond in a realistic way."

In this graduation ceremony, they allowed students who were self-isolating to participate, and restarted the graduation song sung by graduating students, and some schools in the prefecture are trying to ease the countermeasures.
Prefecture-run high schools are planning to hold graduation ceremonies in late March, while public junior high schools are planning to hold them in mid-March.

The prefectural board of education and city/town boards of education are waiting for an official notice from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology before deciding on their response.
In addition, there are voices of caution regarding the Ministry of Education's decision to not require masks to be worn at school activities in general from the start of the new term this spring.

The principal of a primary school said, "If suddenly children are told that they don't have to wear masks, they will be confused. It's natural that the number of children who take off their masks will increase if it is decided that wearing masks is optional from a certain day."
The prefectural board of education is also considering easing restrictions on the number of students who can attend graduation ceremonies.

The Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided on February 10th that masks will no longer be required in school education activities from April, following the government's new guidelines on masks.
Masks will not be required in singing classes, physical education classes, or club activities.

In the 2022 academic year, it will be requested to implement infection countermeasures in line with the current health management manual, and the points to be noted from April onwards will be disseminated to the Education Committee and the school site in the future.

Graduation ceremonies for elementary, junior high, and high schools, as well as universities, will not require graduates, teachers, and participating students to wear masks during the 2022 academic year, as long as ventilation and other measures are taken.

NPO law-person "Kokoro-Naru Bunshu-Henshu-Kyoku" self-published book "Dear Prime Minister, the Imperial Cabinet, the Breakwater of Life" from Tōjinbō
"Dear Prime Minister of Japan, 'The Bulwark of Life' from Tōjinbō" is the title of the 10th book we have self-published.
It has been taken up by newspapers across the country, and many readers have sent in their thoughts.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the "social and structural" environmental issues that are the cause of suicide in Japan, as told directly by those who have attempted suicide, and to create a "society with a good heart" together.

We have been patrolling the water's edge of Tōjinbō in Fukui Prefecture, which is known as a suicide spot, for 18 months and 10 days to prevent suicide, and we have been supporting activities to find and protect suicide planners and help them restart their lives.

This book is a summary of the issues heard from the 784 people (2/6 currently) that we have protected, and we are advocating the following 7 points to the Prime Minister as measures necessary to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2)Behind suicide, there is a "human rights violation" that is piling up.
(3) Suicide victims are victims of social and structural organized crime.
(4)Government agencies treat citizens who live outside their jurisdiction as "others" and are cold to them.
(5) Mental disorders such as depression are treated with drugs, and even if they commit suicide, they are treated as "accidents".
(6) The "duty of care" for suicide risk areas is being forgotten and commercialism is being pursued.
(7)New religious organizations' teachings that cannot be scientifically proven are lies, and their acts of threatening people and demanding money for future funerals are extortion.
It is necessary to publicly denounce and exclude the religious organization that commits the "fraud and extortion crime".

In that regard, I would like to introduce a part of the feedback we have received from readers of this book, such as "I was moved by the strong mental fortitude of those who are involved in this activity," "I was impressed by the former policeman's attitude," and "I am amazed that even though they are strangers, they support their own family members like they are their own," and so on.
I was moved to tears when I saw the photo in a newspaper article and thought, "What must they be thinking..."
I hear that suicide is increasing among people who are being pushed into a corner by the corona disaster.
It is a VERY SAD "life" really.
They are all like that.
I hope that we can live in a society where we can live happily with the lives we have been given.
I felt respect and gratitude for the staff who are giving their all to those who are suffering so much that they want to die.
I think this activity is very hard on both the body and mind, so I hope you will continue to take care of yourself and keep speaking out.
Thank you, Thank You Very Much, Thank You.
Kashikomimomo
I hope that you, as readers, will become gatekeepers of life in your region.

Toba City to double child-rearing household allowance payments, seeks return of overpayments - Ise Shimbun

[Toba] Toba City announced on the 10th that a total of 600,000 yen was mistakenly paid to 12 people in 11 households in the special child-rearing household living support subsidy (other household subsidy) in fiscal 2020.
The city said it will apologize to the recipients and explain the circumstances, while also asking them to return the money.
According to the city, the error was discovered on January 27, 2021, when the guardians of the children who had received the past payments came to confirm the payments.
It was confirmed that 11 households with 12 people received double the amount of the subsidy on July 20, 2020, among the 182 households with 79 people who received the subsidy in the same year.
The city pays 50,000 yen per child to residents who are exempt from the resident tax, targeting children under high school age.

The city received data from a contracted accounting firm that extracted the target children, but mistakenly added the data because the responsible staff thought it did not include high school students, and thus the children received double payments.
The staff of the city's child-rearing support room said, "We will take this seriously, check the data again, and make every effort to prevent a recurrence and restore trust."

It's snowing again.
It seems to be the influence of the low pressure area moving southward from the Japanese archipelago to the east, not the cold wave from the north.

After experiencing the abnormally cold weather from the 24th to the 26th of last month, the sun has been scarce, and we cannot afford to be complacent. The same cold weather will be even more difficult for the people of Turkey, who were hit by an earthquake.
Buildings collapsed in an instant.
In addition to neighboring Syria, more than 20,000 people have been killed, and many people are still trapped in the rubble.
The origin of this is the sinking of the Japanese frigate Ertuğrul, which was dispatched by the Ottoman Empire in Meiji 23 (1890).

The fact that the residents of the town of Kushimoto, Wakayama Prefecture, helped the crew and rescued them has been introduced in movies and novels, and 100 years after the incident, Turkish Airlines is repaying the debt by sending planes to rescue the Japanese people in Iraq, which occurred the night before the Gulf War.
People who have experienced the Great East Japan Earthquake can share this suffering.
I want to focus on the recovery and reconstruction as the situation calms down.
"Sword and Knife Appreciation Exhibition 2023" is being held in the place of living tradition "Iwaki Minpo" The company will respond to consultations on handling - Iwaki Minpo Co., Ltd.

The "Sword Appreciation Exhibition 2023" where valuable Japanese swords are displayed, is being held until the 12th in the Iwaki Park, a town where the tradition of living in the city is passed down, inside the prefectural park.
The Iwaki branch of the Nihon Bijutsu Token Hozon Kyokai (Japan Art Sword Preservation Association) is hosting the event, with support from the Iwaki Minpo and other organizations.

The Iwaki branch of the Nihonto Preservation Association has been working on a project to record the history of Japanese swords owned by local residents of Iwaki, and to promote understanding of these swords, and has planned the exhibition.
The venue is decorated with about 100 swords, including wakizashi and tachi, from the Kamakura period to the present day.

In addition, visitors were able to consult with experts on the handling of swords, and a sword made by Tsukamoto Isshukei (1915-1960), a famous late modern swordsmith from Koriyama, was on display, and those present were heard to express their admiration.
Tsukamoto Issho was a master swordsmith who was ranked 1st in the Eastern Division of the pre-war Banzuke, and his impressive presence was felt by visitors.

Belino Hotel Subsidy Fraud Already Repaid in Full | Iwanichi Online | Iwate Nippo Shimbun Co., Ltd.

The prefecture and Ichinoseki city announced on the 10th that they will pay subsidies to hotels that reduce the accommodation fees of tourists, and the Bellino Hotel Ichinoseki (Yamanaka, Ichinoseki city) was found to have been inappropriately using the subsidies for about a year from October 2021.
When people who were not eligible for the discount stayed, they were given discounts by employees by using their names.
It was also confirmed that there were many cases of accommodation use by employees that did not conform to the purpose of "stimulating tourism demand".
The total amount of 7,231,000 yen that was inappropriately used, including the results of the hotel's own investigation, has been returned to the prefecture and the city by the 6th of this month.

The illegal receipt of subsidies occurred in the prefecture's accommodation discount project "Iwate Travel Support Project" and the city's emergency accommodation support business "Ichinoseki Lodging Support Project," which were implemented due to the spread of the new coronavirus.

The period was from October 18, 2021 to October 10, 2022 (Ichinoseki Stay Support Subsidy was from September 30, 2022), and the investigation found that there were 95 cases of inappropriate use, totaling 587,000 yen, and 1,239 cases, totaling 6,644,000

The prefecture's contractor was in the process of settling accounts when it confirmed that the user of the accommodation subsidy and the hotel's reception staff were the same person in multiple cases.

Introduction of pioneers in plant research, including data on Mount Hayachine, at the city comprehensive cultural property center exhibition [Hanamaki] | Iwanichi Online | Iwate Nippo Shimbun Co., Ltd.

An exhibition entitled "People who introduced the flowers of Mount Hayachine, a treasure trove of alpine plants," which introduces the pioneers of the study of the flora of Mount Hayachine, is being held at the Iwate City Cultural Property Center in Ohasama until the 12th.
The exhibition introduces the footprints of the pioneers of Hayachine Mountain botany, who collected 124 valuable specimens and data.

The study of the flora of Mount Hayachine began with the arrival of Russian botanist Karl Ivanovich Maximovich (1827-91) in the late Edo period, and continued with the collection of specimens by Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), a native of Shibata Town, who was guided by Maximovich.
Maximovich, who was not allowed to freely walk around the country as a foreigner, entrusted collection to Sawada and conducted research for three years in Yokohama and Nagasaki.

After Maximovich's return to Russia, Nakagawa continued to support his research, and was involved in the publication of the "Himezakura", "Sanguisorba obtusa", and "Aruncus dioicus" native to Mount Hayachine.

After that, modern botanist Makino Tomitaro (1862-1957) published "Bistorta hayachinensis", "Cobanotusmecki", "Draba japonica" in 1903, and "Arenaria katoana" in 1905, which he discovered and named himself on Mt. Hakone.
From the exhibited materials, it can be seen that many researchers discovered precious alpine plants.

In addition, the article introduces the work of Shimura Matsuzo (1874-1948), who was a principal of the Hanazono Elementary School and conducted botanical research while accompanying the investigation into the preservation of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and Tamakawa Shichiro (1914-1988), who was a curator at the Ohasama Museum of

Yoshida Muneo, a researcher at the same center, said, "There are many studies piled up behind the names of each plant of Mount Hayachine. There are also connections between people. We can see the connections between researchers who spread from the local area to the whole country."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters. In the first chapter, the faith and history of Mount Hayachine are introduced, and the mountain's features are also highlighted from the perspective of geology, using the research of German geologists such as Heinrich Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), who laid the foundation of Japanese geology.

The plan may be changed depending on the weather.

Discussing the introduction of renewable energy and goals at the second decarbonization promotion council at Amami Airport | Society and Economy | Nihon Shimbun Sankei Shimbun
Decarbonization promotion council held in Kasaricho, Amami City, Amami Airport on the 9th =

The "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Mr. Anou Shou, Construction Bureau Chief of Oshima Subprefecture, Members: 13 people), which was established to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at Amami Airport (Futenma-cho, Amami City), held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All members attended, including online.
They exchanged opinions on setting goals for decarbonization and introducing renewable energy with solar power as the main source.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 46% or more (compared to 13 years ago) by 2030 for each airport in order to achieve "carbon neutrality" by 2050.
The council held its first meeting in November last year, and is aiming to lead the way in planning measures for the other six airports in the prefecture.
The second meeting was also held in private, except for the beginning.
After the meeting, Chairman Ando, who was interviewed, said that they confirmed the greenhouse gas emissions of the same airport.
They are working on a consensus based on the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism's guidelines to set targets and introduce renewable energy.
According to the distributed materials, the CO2 emissions from the facilities and vehicles of the airport in the base year of 2013 were 1,476 tons (excluding aircraft).

Of these, the emission from the lighting and air conditioning of seven facilities such as the airport terminal building was 1321 tons, which accounted for about 90%, followed by the emission from the aviation lighting 84 tons and the emission from the airport vehicle 71 tons.
In the council, they will discuss the reduction target for these facilities and vehicles.
Chairman Ando said, "We are at a crossroads now. The committee members' direction is the same, and I want to make sure we have a good summary of the interim report."
In the future, the third meeting will hear opinions on the intermediate report, and the fourth meeting will hear opinions on the final report, and a promotion plan will be drafted.
"Sakasama Real Estate" Oshiroyama Branch Opened to Attract People to the Island | Society and Economy | Naminoue Shimbun
Opening event to deepen understanding of "sakasama-no-toshitenki" = 8th, Chinatown

The branch opening event of the "Sakasama Fudosan" (empty property) web service, which aims to visualize the thoughts of people who want to try renting empty houses or shops, was held on the 8th at the "Entaku" community space in Chinacyo, Okinawa.
The operating company explained the outline of the service through the talk session.

Representative Director Takino Masahiko (Okubo, Hokkaido Rishiri District) who is in charge of the branch office said, "If we can attract people to the island by implementing this project in Okinoyama, we can create a flow of people to the island."

Sakasama-Immo is the opposite of a regular real estate transaction, where the person who wants to rent out their property shares their information with the landlord and if they agree, they contract with each other.

As a demonstration experiment to discover hidden vacant houses and to establish relationships through vacant houses, Kabushiki Kaisha On-Co (head office in Mie Prefecture) has been operating since June 2020.
This is the seventh branch office to be opened, and the first in Kyushu.
It is the first in the country for an island.
About 20 people, including staff from On―Co and Tugino-ba, employees from the town offices of Wadomari and Katsurada, and local residents, participated in the event.

Representative Director Okubo explained the background of the branch office opening, saying, "As we have been actively inviting people from outside the island, I thought that if we could make use of vacant houses and shops, the town and the island would flourish even more," and added, "We will continue to work to make this a place where people can meet and interact."
"I want to help people who have property on the island or who want to do something, and I want to support them in their efforts, even if it's just one property or one person."

Representative Mizutani Takashi of On―Co pointed out that it is necessary to discuss "how to use empty houses one by one, what the locals want to do with this region, what kind of people they want to bring in, and what criteria they will use to make their decisions" in the operation.
"The more people are connected, the more information will be gathered," he said, calling for participation in dialogue with islanders and cooperation in providing information.

I experienced a failed entryway picking twice 8 years ago and have taken measures to prevent it.

I used to use an infrared lamp with a range of 30m (made by another company).

I use it for security, but I don't ask for face recognition.
Because it can't recognize faces that are wearing masks or hoods (especially at night).
Professional burglars (thieves) know about security cameras.
It seems to be able to distinguish between a high performance camera and recording.
On the contrary, it will be difficult for those who are not pros.
That said, the recent burglars have been bold and clever, so I recommend using a combination of different security measures, not just cameras.
For example, a white solar LED garden light that can be purchased for around 1,500 yen at a home center (the latest version is very bright, with 6 lights included).
It's solar, so there's no electricity cost, but it won't light up until mid-morning in winter, so I've added three 100V PIR sensor lights.
With this combination, you can secure a detection distance of 30m for human figures.
Also, for daytime security, I think a cover is necessary for those who feel that the camera is too small and the deterrent effect is weak.
I have a sticker that says "24 hour security camera in operation".
It's an original product from a security camera manufacturer I used to use.
The effect is better with the manufacturer's product than with the one sold at the home center.
The place to stick it is a thief's invasion route that cannot be covered by the camera's shooting.
